reviewText:
Few games can set new standards for technical failure and gameplay lack-of-design, but Temper Tantrum stands tall with Redneck Racers as example of what someone can produce when the goal is to create the absolute minimum of what can be called a game. This copy was provided by the developer in a giveaway to collect feedback, which I have every intention of giving in the fullest.

From the very start Temper Tantrum is off on the wrong foot. The music, a bland, short, and repetitive loop is blaring in my ears, and the game provides no audio sliders or, as best as I can tell, no options menu whatsoever. Nothing is labeled such when you start the game, and hitting Escape, P, or Start on a gamepad don't bring up any sort of menu. After manually adjusting the volume for the program in the Windows audio mixer I decided I would try to play the game...a foolish notion on my part. I first tried with WASD and it immediately felt awkward, so I picked up my controller in the hopes that would help, but it was only marginally (and I do mean by the tiniest margin) better. As far as I can tell—if you hear me saying this a lot, it's because the game doesn't explain itself whatsoever and I'm mostly left fumbling trying to figure it out—there are no camera controls, and most of the time you can't actually see where you're going. The only way to see anything is stop moving; if you stand still for a second the camera will swing back behind you. The only other button that appears do anything is Y, which is jump (why Y?).

The actual gameplay of Temper Tantrum is simple enough. Run around, bump into stuff, get points, avoid some monster. I've yet, however, to find any reason to continue playing this game beyond what it took to write this review. Even if it worked flawlessly it's simple to the point of boredom, looks atrocious, and is littered with bugs. You will often find your view clipping through the wall (completely blocking your view), or yourself partially clipping through a wall and touching objects on the other side, which though not entirely unwelcome while trying to get through this, should certainly not happen. My first go 'round had me stuck on the first level because the game insisted I had one item left to break despite going through the whole house multiple times and finding nothing. My only way to escape was to die until the game ended because of the aforementioned lack of any form of pause menu. Second run went much smoother and I was able to clear it easily, along with the next level, but eventually I gave up because I just could not stand playing the game any longer. There's a monster that follows you around at a snail's pace, but frankly the camera is more dangerous than the monster; the only way the monster will ever get you is if you can't see it. There's also candy left on the ground that acts like a power pellet and makes you kill the monster on contact, another thing I had to learn by trial and error since the game didn't explain anything at all. You can only pick up one at a time (which was what had me confused at first, how sometimes they picked up and sometimes they didn't), but they're plentiful enough you'll rarely have to worry about it, at least in the levels I played. Maybe the monster becomes a genuine threat in later levels, but I'd be surprised if anyone had the patience to play that much of the game. Oh, and as one final bug I noticed, numbers will often be rendered on top of each other.

In short, I feel that Temper Tantrum is a complete waste of time. There was not one single redeeming factor in my time with it that I felt could make it enjoyable to anyone at any price point. Not for 99 cents, not the current sale of 24 cents, not even for free. Just save yourself the time and find something better to play instead.

reviewText:
Sometimes, there are games that make you question about the kind of stuff that game developers smoke.  I have seen my share of strange games and I have seen utterly terrible games.  This combines both in a blender, and not one of those fancy type blenders.  I'm talking the low quality made in Uganda kind of stuff.  Wait, are blenders made in Uganda?  Maybe I should have a look.

There was this crazy action film made in Uganda, actually.  It was titled Who Killed Captain Alex.  The trailer was really strange and the movie was hard to understand.  But yet I felt that there was more effort to the making of Uganda's first action film than this game.  And really, this game really sets a low bar.  You'd need a Jamaican limbo athlete in order to get under that bar.  It's that bad.

Let's start with the most basic feature, the control.  You probably could run around a little bit... and jump.  Nope.  No other buttons.  There's no kicking, punching, headbutting, barrel rolling, smash attacks, etc.  You name it, you can't do it.  Instead, you run into low-quality 3d furniture and after a few moments, it disappears with a cheap special effect and you get some points.  That's pretty much all you do, run into furniture and avoid ghosts with creepy nicknames.  Oh, you pick up candy and immediately lose all sense of control as you aimlessly run around and into ghosts while under a sugar rush. This costs money to buy.  Nobody knows why.

It's stupidly simple and even then, it fails to even get the basics right. The level counter is bugged and doesn't even work correctly.  The combo counter stopped working after a while (aptly labeled Combo Break, btw).  There is zero camera control.  On one map, during a countdown before giving you control, a ghost will touch you before the level begins and you instantly lose a chance.  Something is dreadfully wrong when it fails to get the very basics correct.

There are claims that it's supposed to play like Pac-Man, but there's a big difference.  Pac-Man is actually a fun arcade game that is considered legendary of the 80s arcade scene.  This game falls way behind.  I feel that this is more of a cheap attempt at being Goat Simulator, missing the point in the process by a country mile.

The graphics is as basic as it gets, similar to a game from the PS1/N64 era, but with a modern screen resolution.  You could probably play it on the most basic Dell pre-built, but why would you want to in the first place?  You can get a sense of where the creepy ghosts are, as long as they're in the view of the camera.  But if you get in a spot in which the wall blocks your camera view?  Yeah, good luck with that.  The loading screens are also terrible and ugly,  There's little else to say.

And the sound and music? Psh. There's only one music track.  Get used to it.  That's all the music you get to hear.  Sound effects are also very basic, much like everything else.  Did I mention that this game costs money?

Amazing how an utterly lame and basic game is so technically problematic and yet somehow shows up in the Steam store, costing actual money?  Someone got drunk when approving" this game.  And the worst part of all this
date: it costs money to buy this game.  Don't buy it for yourself

Oh, good lord, where to begin? The game made me nauseous in about 5 minutes, which is a new record. Even Two Worlds 2 took about fifteen minutes for its infamous camera to take an effect on me. If you do manage to play the game long enough, there are only three levels that repeat. Kind of makes me wish for a “You’re Winner” splash screen, it’d be less of a slap in the face..

As people are figuring out, the graphics for the game are basically stolen from three Unity Asset Packs.
3DRT-Toonworld Interiors: https://www.assetstore.unity3d.com/en/#!/content/13533
Generic Cute Male: https://www.assetstore.unity3d.com/en/#!/content/11675
Jelly Monsters: https://www.assetstore.unity3d.com/en/#!/content/19176
It’s almost inspiring in a way, where I could buy some asset packs, add some actual creativity and crap out a better game than this.

Digital Homicide LLC is the Brokencyde of game developers, obnoxious as hell and utterly irredeemable.

reviewText:
This game could be fun, but has far too many issues to entertain for more than 5 minutes, so currently I can't reccomend this game.

The current problems I found:

1. Controls feel like you're sliding on a pan of butter, with banana peels on your feet, while being covered in oil.
2. No story, no reason for the baby to be upset
3. Baby is a weirdo with only a smile, while destroying a home, no other emotion/animation
4. Only 3 levels, repeating, and repeating.
5. There are missing textures on some sweets (checkerboard pattern)
6. No pause menu or main menu (gotta alt+F4 to quit)
7. Camera is unbearable (clips through every object, doesn't quite keep up with the character's speed (that baby is FAST)


Now, there ARE ways I personally feel things could work for this game.

1. Give players a good interface (Main menu, Pause Menu, all that jazz)
2. Fix the controls, make the controls actually feel as if you're running, instead of hovering oddly.
3. Add more levels, and maybe Item placement randomness.
4. A story, small and simple, that'd be all that's needed.
5. More emotion to the baby.
6. Better player to object collision.
7. Possibly a method of breaking the stuff (like an attack button, could be smashing furniture with toys instead of just bumping).
8. Better relative size to environment (baby is massive).

All these suggestions are personal opinions, but I do figure a lot of the community can agree with at least some of them.

reviewText:
Want to experience torture by playing a video game? Well look no further than Temper Tantrum by Digital Homicide Studios.

The main draw of this game is seeing furniture explode. While I do think that is a good concept, it was poorly executed. Normally you get weapons, attack animations, and anything to make it look like you did something to earn a flashy explosion. Instead, you run into the furniture, it explodes, move on the next furniture, and continue until you’ve destroyed everything.

The mechanics for the enemies are odd. Whenever I start-up a new game, I normally get 1 enemy. But sometimes I get all 3 enemies at the first level. Their movement speed is a joke. You can easily outrun them, but to balance this out, they go through walls. And no, nothing in the game’s description said they were ghosts.

While the enemies aren’t too bad in this game, the real enemy is the camera. This camera goes wherever it feels like once you take a single step. It moves so much that it kind of makes me nauseous after looking at it for a long period of time. It doesn’t help that the only way you can control the camera is by moving your character.

The graphics, in all honesty, are ugly! Everything is all bright in the worst way possible. Seriously, who would design their poor home this way? Lil’ Johnny and the enemies look completely different in comparison to the environment they are in. It is as if the designer didn’t have time to put much detail into the environment and used it on a baby and three spheres.

Overall, this game is awful with nothing to redeem it whatsoever. In my opinion, I’m glad it’s only three levels long because I got tired of it after reaching level four. If you are THAT curious on seeing how bad this game is, like I was, there’s nothing to stop you from playing it.

reviewText:
Possibly the best game I have had the pleasure of playing.

In this hidden jewel of a game you take control of the child Johnny and have the fun of destroying everything around you. But this game is not just summed up by its many minutes of content. The developers knew that some people dont only play games for content and instead crave a well developed lore.

In my extensive playthrough of this game I have noticed that despite that happy colorful exterior that the game presents, temper tantrum hides a dark and twisted lore, and the developers have hidden this in a similar way as Scott Cawthon the developer of the recently popular Five Nights At Freddy's game series. This is done by the game not openly telling you the lore but instead making the player delve deep to find it themselves.

This is my summary of the lore. (This is entirely subjective and may or may not be canon)

The first creature you will encounter in temper tantrum is the elusive enemy only known as Mr NightNight who is the living manifestation of Johnny's regrets as Night Night were the last words he said to his Parents, Babysitter and Grandparents before he brutally murdered them. This regret is embodied as the Mr NightNight we see in the game and the reason it  puts you to sleep is because when the guilt catches up to Johnny he can't cope with it and sadly kills himself resulting in his naptime, permanently.

Then you have an encounter with Mr Sleepytime who is the living manifestation of Johnnys insomnia as every time he tries to sleep he is encountered by visions of what he did and it scares johnny so much that it deprives him of this much needed sleep, and if Mr Sleepytime catches up to little Johnny then he realises he will never sleep again and this fear causes him to again, kill himself resulting in his permanent naptime.

Finally when you get far into this game you encounter the most terrifying of them all, Mr Boogerman Mr Boogerman is the beast within johnny that made him kill all of the people in his past and when he catches up to Johnny he will control him to make him kill himself. Which once again results in his permanent naptime.

In temper tantrum you work to destroy the evidence of your crimes while avoiding your past, your present and your future, disguised as a happy experience this game has one of the most twisted and well developed lores I have come across in my gaming.

reviewText:
The camera angles are ridiculously bad, along with the camera on the player itself. It makes running around more like 'a chore' instead of being fun.
The soundtrack is okay but is repetitive. I've also encountered blatantly obvious invisible barriers, such as with the pool making you either walk on water or walk in the air.
The 'Mr Night Night' isn't that much of a challenge, and if he was the game would be even worse because the camera makes it really hard to even MOVE.
The textures are extremely low quality, but this is a minor issue.
Outside you are essentially in 'a blue hell', if the game had made a neighbourhood or something it'd be a lot better than just nothing but blue.
The menu screen seemingly has no 'start', and looks plain weird. The loading screen is also like this, but just a pasted image that isn't very high quality.
If you want replayability, there's no replayability.

The concept is quite interesting, but a bit linear. If the game was polished and improved, this would be a short, semi-linear but fun game.

Overall, I wouldn't purchase this game if I were you, even though I got it for like $0.25USD.

(Short Review) Digital Suicide
Two of the most feared words on the Steam Community are Digital Homicide. Why? Well, if the disaster that was The Slaughtering Grounds and it's crusade agaisnt criticism (and Jim Sterling) isn't enough for you... they don't make their games, or for that fact, make anything. Instead, the 2 people behind D.H. buy assets, slop them together, put whatever green-ish slime monstrosities they've created on Steam Greenlight, and wait for the money to roll in. Regardless of their shady, yet somehow legal (but, sometimes almost illegal) activities, they managed to get a few squirts out, and Temper Tantrum was one of them.

Now, I never played any of their previous games, or hell, even watched a single video about Temper Tantrum before I bought it, but the second I booted the game up, I already knew what I was in for. Not only is the application literally named 'Assets' (no joke), but, the menu screen alone made my eyes burn. I'm sure the artists that had their work stollen here put allot of heart and soul into the assets they created, but, something about their use here was awful. To put it lightly, it's bright, but not in a good way. Then I hit start, and the ♥♥♥♥ really started hitting the fan.

If you've ever played a third-person game, or infinite running game, you know the controls are simple, and, if done right, they won't make you want to shove the camera's head up it's own ♥♥♥. Temper Tantrum is a different case. It seems to me like the controls for both of the genres listed above were mashed together with no effort, as this game is such a ♥♥♥♥ing pain to play that the only reason I left it open for 2 hours was for cards. More on the gameplay side, besides the awkward controls and god awful camera, the gameplay itself is pretty abysmal, too. Basically, you run into stuff, wait, run into more stuff, and the process repeats. This wouldn't be so terrible if the camera and controls weren't so bad, but, because I'd have an easier time ice skating with 2 ice cream cookies strapped to my feat, and a pillow sheet taped to my face, it just has an awful, cheap, and all around bad feeling to it. To add insult to injury, the obnoxious music repeats itself to the point where either I was going to mute the sound, or the sound was going to mute me... from ever wanting to listen to music again.

Temper Tantrum is bad... really, really bad. Even if it were one of those Wii shovelware titles, it'd probably be one of the worst. The only redeeming quality about Temper Tantrum is the cards, and then an eventual refund. There are several ironic things sorrounding the overall consensus of Digital Homicide's activity: one of which is that at one point, Digital Homicide spent more money buying assets and putting them on greenlight under fake accounts, than it would to create an actual prototype of a game full of not stollen assets... and, that Steam Refunds are ironing out what little gratiousness this appalling business practice of their's is. Overall, do I recommend Temper Tantrum? No. Not at all. I couldn't even get past the first level because, in all honesty, it was ♥♥♥♥. And because I know these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s can be so sensitive to criticism at times, if for some odd, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t reason this review gets pulled, it'll be on my blog, this part included.

TL;DR: Don't buy this game, or even look at it. It's controls, camera, and gameplay prevent from being any fun. However, if you're into cards... just buy them from the market yourself and re-sell them. It's not worth picking this game up even for cards.

reviewText:
Temper Tantrum is one of the few games that can evoke true emotions in the player. Honestly, the gaming experience of our generation. People hate this game because of the developer and the fact that the game is seemingly made for kids, but yet they are missing out on the underrated gem of the gaming world due to their blind hatred. If you actually immerse yourself in Temper Tantrum, you will find that it is a gaming experience that should not be missed.

Story 10/10
Temper Tantrum's story is very reminiscent of games like Shadow of the Colossus in the sense that it is very interpretive. Are you evil for murdering those innocent looking blob monsters, or is it just self defense? Questions like these keep me awake at night, pondering this brilliant game. The story of this game is a beautiful statement on sentience and the meaning of life.

Gameplay 10/10
The gameplay of this game is smooth and enjoyable. Truly top notch gameplay. The only problem one may have is the camera, which can occasionally be a little bit sub par, but it is only that way to symbolize the mediocrity of life. Beautiful symbolizism, fantastic gameplay.

Graphics 10/10
Simply put, this game is art. It's as simple as that.

Music 10/10
My playlist is comprised solely of this game's soundtrack. It's that good.

Overall 10/10
Temper Tantrum is the Citizen Kane of games. Underappreciated at the time that it came out, but hopefully will be recognized for the masterpiece that it is in the future. Sheer brilliance

reviewText: The controls take some getting used to, but do not hinder gameplay once you adapt to them. The camera is reminiscent of early 3D games, which is not a good thing. However, aside from those issues, the game is actually pretty good! The story and gameplay are simple, but enjoyable. You are hired by numerous relatives and friends, all of which have some form of insurance, to destroy all the items protected under said insurance plans. You collect 40% of the insurance check issued to those that hire you to destroy their belongings. As you gain more money, you can buy a large variety of destructive tools. Earlier tools are small, simple, and cheap, such as sledgehammers and cinder blocks. Later on, you can buy the much more expensive but much more destructive RPG and flamethrower. There is not a whole lot of enemy variety, but that is okay. Enemies come in the form of robotic spies attempting to track your activities and report the insurance fraud to their respective agencies. They attempt to capture you; if they touch you, they will restrain you and deliver you to their agencies as hard proof of insurance fraud. Some of them have technology that give them advantages in capturing you, such as going through walls. Honestly, the game is not that long, but for only a dollar (I bought it for 10 cents, and at the time of writing this review, it is on sale for 50 cents), it is well worth the price. If I could (and I did, so I could gift this to my friends), I would spend more money on this game! The developers deserve much more than a single dollar for their hard work. I am still looking forward to the much hyped downloadable content.\n\nIn short: If you are looking for a game similar to Hatred (which ripped off of this game anyway), but do not want all the re­tarded overly-edgy dialogue and sickening gore, and/or want a game that is actually fun to play, then I highly recommend picking this title up.

I'm going to hit 4 points that I got from this video and I'm going to give this game an overall score.....

1.) Graphics - the graphics in this are superb, with the frostbite 4 engine, the destruction could never be any better. Overall, I think this game has top notch graphics that compete with the best AAA games on the market. The sound is superb, what else can I say? The game play is revolutionary, taking from the perspective of a kid wrecking a house while his parents aren't home, being a little pleb. I would not recommend this to anyone under the age of 17. But over all it's 10/10

reviewText:
Temper Tantrum is a game where you play a restless spirit possesing a mostly naked toddler. Infuriated at your host's lack of basic motor skills, you use your eldritch powers to lash out at your nearby environs. Unfortunately, you are not the only specter to break out of your eternal confinement, and several of your peers are chasing you, desperate to get you back to the netherrealm so you can pay them back the ectoplasm you owe them.

You can augment your fell enchantments with sugary treats, giving you the power to temporarily banish your phantasmagorial adversaries from this plane, but they will always be back. And as much as you may destroy, and as far as you run, they are many, and you are but a fussy supernatural toddler. Should you escape the third level, they shall simply cast the runes of summoning to whisk you back to the first level again, an endless cycle of torment not unlike what awaits you in the pit.

The game is horrifically loud, the controls are wonky, and there's not much to the game other than trying to come up with your best pretentious garbage way of describing it in a review. But it does run properly, and I can't say I feel like I wasted the 25 cents I paid. So, follow your heart or w/e

I was wondering if I should purchase this game or not during the steam sale. The steep price of $0.08 turned me away at first but after watching many gamers review this game, I knew that I had to buy it.

First off, I'd like to say that this game is NOT for the faint of heart. This game is for people who have extremely strong stomachs and know how to play games well under pressure. Within this very game, you will have to absolutely trash your parents’ house. I'm not saying a few people over, having a get together trash. I'm talking about ripping doors off of frames, obliterating couches, and demolishing tables to avoid nap time.

The storyline might be a little hard to follow especially if you haven't played the first one, but you should be able to catch yourself up within the first two chapters. The best part of the story line is definitely the ending. I will NOT spoil it for anyone but there is a definite plot twist at the end.

If I haven't stressed this enough, this isn't a game for casuals. This game is solely played for competition and if you don't play the tutorial, you will be screwed.

The replay value of this game is superb. I love competing with others to get the highest score possible. This game is a masterpiece. The settings are intuitive, the gameplay is extremely smooth and addicting, and the sound quality is far beyond what any other game can offer. I recommend this game to any gamer who has spent years perfecting their trade. This game is much underrated and I would expect to see YouTube gamers to pick this game up within the next couple of months. 1080/10, would buy again.

reviewText:
This game is amazing.
No, really. I mean it. Like, honestly mean it.

To truly understand what this game is about, we have to look deeper than just its mechanics and flaws.
Forget about the sloppy controls, forget about non-existent camera controls, about camera going through walls rendering you blind, the slowly aggravating music making you clinically insane, ghosts being able to kill you before the level starts, you being able to destroy items through walls, the controls that are in settings but aren't actually in the game, High score font doubling, somehow being overpriced despite being 0,24 Euros (0,99 Euros after sales).

The game, essentially, is you playing as a naked toddler, somehow being able to run around the house, destroying furniture on contact with explosions. Now, this might sound really stupid, but it actually has meaning behind the small details put into the game.

Let's start with the point of the game. Destruction.
Destruction is the act of of destroying something to the point of either it not being able to function or, which is our case, it not even existing. This can have multiple outcomes on the meaning of this function.
Existential crisis.
You play as a child. A very young child, who can still walk and run flawlessly. That is not a crazy nonsense, it means that you really play as a grown man going through his midlife crisis. He becomes childish again and wants to destroy everything around him. The ghosts here represent other factors stopping him from his masculine needs, making him tired and falling asleep.
War.
Arguably, every war also creates something, act of creation through ultimate destruction and annihilation. But not here. This a critique of war. You, as a soldier, just endlessly walk around the same set of planes again and again, destroying everything that doesn't belong to you, killing everyone maybe just trying to protect itself, consuming the sweets, labors of your awful work, driving you forward to kill more. Your character is so psychotic, that it doesn't even need explanation to his actions, just orders. Destroy everything. Everything is even begging you to destroy it, to break it.
I'd also like to point out that hovering over the models reveals the name of the ghost again. That, in my opinion, can mean that people truly are bland, the same inside as on the outside.


Now, for the actual good sides of the game
The game is Pac-Man in 3 dimensions with tad bit different designs and I like that idea. This could be remade to be actually good. If it was designed better with few more functions, like punching the furniture instead of just touching it, if it had better controls, movements and camera, it would be a fun game, maybe even worth the price.
I'd also like to praise them modeling the house outside, so when go through the wall with the camera, you can't see the endless void. Also, the model of the child looks pretty good, too. It's anime-esque with nice looking hair and textures. Of course, the developer could just steal all of his assets, but who would possibly, actually do something like that, right?
And for Christ's sake, the game is the price of a chocolate bar. Do you really expect it to be any good? Sure, it's a game to be ashamed of making, not something you should charge for, but who would actually want it?
Just don't buy it, 'cause the developer is a well-known piece of s*** great human being that should be worshiped for her/his art.
Please don't take this review down. Thank you.
PS: xoxo luv ya, DigitalHomicide.
